typedef std::vector< SEdge > GrPolygonGroup::EdgeVec

Definition at line 47 of file GrPolygonGroup.h.

typedef std::vector< GrPolygon* > GrPolygonGroup::PolygonVec

note that PolygonVec must be an array of some sort. This is because we do a &_polygons.front() to get a pointer to the array. This is a blatant hack, but it gives a decent speed increase when fixing t-junctions.

void GrPolygonGroup::GenEdgeList ( EdgeVec &  edges  ) 

Edge list generation.

get the current polygon and iterate through it's edges.

note that the neighbor hash has to be from p1->p0 instead of p0->p1. This is because of the winding order of neighboring triangles.

copy edges into the edge vector.

builds a palette of planes to use for splitting from the geometry in the group.

make sure the incoming plane vector is empty.

create a place to store planes and their area.

go through all polygons and ensure they are in a group.

check to see if the current polygon goes into any of the existing groups.

all done with the current polygon since it resides on an existing plane.

now sort the planes by area.

Definition at line 912 of file GrPolygonGroup.cpp.

void GrPolygonGroup::GenTSBasis (  ) 

generates the tangent space basis.

create a place to hold face tangents and binormals.

go through each polygon and create a face tangent and binormal.

make sure we have a valid polygon for the TS basis.

the polygon MUST have a valid UV mapping.

set the vertex flags on the polygon to include a TS basis.

generate the TS basis for the polygon face.

if generating the TS basis failed, then we need to initialize with default data.

make sure we don't have any degenerate cases!

build a spacial partition of our polygons.

this is a list that we build to contain neighboring polygons.

now calculate the tangent and binormal for each vertex. This is similar to smoothing normals on a mesh. Since the triangle linking discriminates normals, we can simply smooth with neighbors (or join neighbors back to back).

get the current polygon.

get the number of vertices in the current polygon and make sure it's valid.

calculate the bounding volume of the current polygon.

get the current position.

calculate the AABB's min corner.

calculate the AABB's max corner.

push the box out by the epsilon amount specified so that we get neighboring polygons.

now do a query for neighboring polygons.

for each vertex...

try to find a polygon that has a similar vertex.

iterate through each neighbor and smooth tangents and binormals.

get the index of the current neighbor polygon.

make sure we don't smooth with ourselves.

smooth with each vertex on the neighbor.

cosine of the tolerance angle (120 degrees).

if the positions and the normals are equal, then we need to calculate orthonormalized tangents and binormals and check to see if they can be smoothed.

Calculate orthonormal tangents and binormals here. They only have to be orthogonal to the normal.

Change this check to use the orthonormalized tangents and binormals. If the tangents and binormals are within a certain margin of error, then we need to smooth them.

change this to use the orthonormalized tangents and binormals. found a match.

record the averaged vectors. check to see if the triangle is too small in UV space. If so, simply make something up.

verify that the tangents created are valid.

This makes sure that the tangent and binormal are right angles to the surface normal.

make sure the tangent is a right angle to the normal.

make sure that the tangent space basis orthogonal. Note that this can be made better by finding the average tangent and binormal that averages the error across the tangent and the binormal. Currently, all of the error lies in the binormal.

calculate the new binormal so that it's a right angle to the tangent and the binormal.

normalize the new binormal.

make sure the resulting tangents and binormals are valid.

Definition at line 202 of file GrPolygonGroup.cpp.

void GrPolygonGroup::SetSkinningInfo ( SPolygonSkinVertex *  skinVertArray,
tstring *  boneNames,
MMat4x4 *  invBindMatrices,
unsigned int  count 
)

Note that this object takes ownership over the pointers passed in.

adds skinning information. There should be one entry for every polygon vertex in the group. This essentially does: for each polygon polygon->SetSkinningInfo( skinVertArray ); skinVertArray += polygon->GetVertexCount();

ensure that the parameters passed in are valid.

set the skinning flag to true.

free the previous arrays if there were any.

set up the data.

we assume that the array passed in has enough skinning info for every polygon. That said, go through each polygon and set the skinning info for it.
